body_content.explanation: to exchange one thing for another thing, especially of a similar type:
examples: She's just changed jobs.
Let's change the subject (= talk about something different).

body_content.explanation: to make or become different:
examples: I almost didn't recognize her - she'd changed so much.
That was 20 years ago and things have changed since then.
Nothing changes, does it - I've been away two years and the office still looks exactly the same.
People have changed their diets a lot over the past few years.
I'm going to change my hairstyle.

body_content.explanation: to take something you have bought back to a shop and exchange it for something else:
examples: I had to change those trousers I bought for (= take them back to the shop in order to get) a bigger pair.

body_content.explanation: to form a new opinion or make a new decision about something that is different from your old one:
examples: If you change your mind about coming tonight, just give me a call.

body_content.explanation: to improve:
examples: Her attitude has definitely changed for the better since she started this new job.

body_content.explanation: to improve the bad parts of your behaviour:
examples: If he wants to carry on living here, he's going to have to change his ways and learn to be a bit less messy.

body_content.explanation: to get off a train, bus, etc. and catch another in order to continue a journey:
examples: I had to change (trains) twice to get there.
Change at Peterborough for York.

body_content.explanation: to get or give money in exchange for money, either because you want it in smaller units, or because you want the same value in foreign money:
examples: Could you change a £10 note (for two fives), please?
Could you change a £5 note for me?
I need to change my dollars for/into English money.

body_content.explanation: to remove one set of clothes and put a different set on yourself or a young child, especially a baby, or to remove dirty sheets from a bed and put clean ones on it:
examples: You don't need to change - you look great as you are.
I'll just change into (= get dressed in) something a bit smarter.
Give me five minutes to change out of (= remove) my work clothes and I'll come out with you.
How often do you think he changes his shirt?
Could you change the baby (= the baby's nappy)?
I've changed the sheets/the bed (= the sheets on the bed) in the guest room.

body_content.explanation: When the wind or the tide (= the rise and fall of the sea) changes, it starts to move in a different direction:
examples: The tide is starting to change.

body_content.explanation: to put a vehicle into a different gear, usually in order to change the speed at which it is moving:
examples: to change gear
I changed into fourth (gear).
Change down to go round the corner.

body_content.explanation: the act of becoming different, or the result of something becoming different:
examples: Let me know if there's any change in the situation.
We're living in a time of great change.
We need a change of government.
a change in lifestyle
They've made a lot of changes to the house.
The new management will make fundamental/radical/sweeping changes (= do things in a very different way).

body_content.explanation: something that is pleasant or interesting because it is unusual or new:
examples: It's nice to see her smile for a change.
"Shall we we eat in the garden?" "Why not - it'll make a change."
We've always had a red car - it's time we had a change!

body_content.explanation: a new situation:
examples: She'd been with the same company for too many years and felt she needed a change of scene, so she applied for a job as a stage manager.

body_content.explanation: money in the form of coins rather than notes:
examples: She gave me €5 in change.
My dad always used to carry a lot of loose/small change (= coins) in his pocket.

body_content.explanation: smaller units of money given in exchange for larger units of the same amount:
examples: Do you have change for a 20-dollar bill?

body_content.explanation: the money that is returned to someone who has paid for something that costs less than the amount that they gave:
examples: I think you've given me the wrong change.

body_content.explanation: the action of putting on different clothes:
examples: She did a quick change before going on TV.

body_content.explanation: a set of clothes as well as the ones that you are wearing:
examples: You'll need a change of clothes if you're staying overnight.

body_content.explanation: the action of getting off a train, bus, etc. and catching another in order to continue a journey:
examples: I hate journeys where you've got a lot of changes.

body_content.explanation:
another name for a 
changeup :
examples: He mixes his fastball in with a change and a slider.
